title: this should be punished harder.
body: a winnable game lost because my jungler went afk. the punishment for going afk is for real nothing. going afk should be on the same level as being toxic or inting.

replies.body:
I mean, I agree that punishments could be harder but it literally wouldn't solve your problem in this scenario.

No matter how strict of a punishment AFKing results in, that guy isn't going to value your game higher than his job. Real life is full of emergencies, which is why the system is so lenient in regards to AFK.

Punishments should be harsher, but people have lives outside of this game. You can't predict literally everything, and it sounds like this guy had something he couldn't plan ahead for. Are you telling me you plan ahead 100% every game? You're never going to face a situation that *requires* you to take care of real life?
its not an Emergency. and he can say no or wait 10 minutes.

If you think a call from your job can't be an emergency, then your priorities are wrong.

A call from the job could be:

"Quick, the store just got robbed!"

"Quick, our critical servers are down!"

Or any millions of other things, all of which are more important that your game of League. If your job description requires you to be available 24/7 in case of emergencies, then you're going to get fired if you're not there ASAP.
I'm my company's network operations manager. You're damn right I've left League games to handle something important. It's extremely infrequent, but it happens.

They will not call you if the store was robbed. Thats just trying to make a point but not really working. 


About the servers. I am sure there is already someone there fixing it and they call to ask if he can help. Not an emergency.

They will if you are the manager.

Not if you are the first contact for tech emergencies.

If my family member falls and breaks their arm, I am taking care of them until they get medical attention (or taking them to get medical care myself).

If my job calls me and says "someone called in sick, can you please come in asap", I'm going to work. Because part of my job is helping, and not valuing a video game over my coworkers not being swamped with work.

I agree. There should me a much more severe punishment for taking a picture of a computer monitor and then scribbling names out rather than using the screenshot button (PrtScn usually but F12 for LoL) and then covering names with a shape tool.

https://i.imgur.com/3qlVoYR.gif[]
That's why I would HATE having a stand by job where they can just call you anytime and you gotta go in. Sorry your video game match was ruined because of it.

To be quite honest, I have such a job, but it is *rare* I am called in. Regardless, technically *everyone* who works a shift job has a standby job - someone calls in sick, you may be called and asked to come in. While not mandatory, who would give up an extra 8 hours of pay (and possible overtime) just to say "no I can't come in for 10 more minutes because I'm playing a video game"?

I have never in 12 years been called to come in to work a shift that i wasnt already scheduled for.

You're either incredibly lucky or your managers hate you :P

I'm not saying it'll happen to everyone - but technically speaking, if you work a shift work job, your manager can call you and *request* (there are limitations on what they can force you to do on short notice depending on jurisdiction) you work an extra shift, starting "ASAP". If you don't go in that second, they may not give you the shift.

That's the choice many people may have to make - especially those less well off for whom 8 hours of pay (or even OT pay) may be the difference between skipping a meal each day this week and being able to eat, or paying rent and being evicted, etc.
